clusters.title: Why did the U.S. ban Anthropic's AI? #world
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump orders government to stop using Anthropic in battle over AI use
bullet_summary: How the agreement came together and why it matters OpenAI announced it has reached an arrangement to deploy its models inside a Defense Department classified network
In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive
The move announced on social media comes after a standoff between Anthropic's boss and the Ministry of Defense
President Trump said he will give federal agencies six months to phase out their use of Anthropic's AI products

items.title: Why did the U.S. ban Anthropic's AI? #world
items.standfirst: How a Pentagon standoff escalated into a federal ban A dispute between Anthropic, a major AI developer, and the U.S. government turned public and culminated in an executive directive that federal agencies stop using the company’s tools. The Defense Department had pressed Anthropic to loosen its…

Pentagon officials pressed Anthropic to allow its AI models to be used for a wide range of military purposes,…

Pentagon officials pressed Anthropic to allow its AI models to be used for a wide range of military purposes,…

items.title: Why is the Pentagon clashing with Anthropic? #tech
items.standfirst: What happened and why it matters The conflict stems from a direct dispute over how Anthropic’s Claude model may be used by the U.S. military. Defense officials demanded contract language that would remove or loosen safety guardrails Anthropic built into its systems, specifically to allow certain…

Company CEO Sam Altman disclosed the agreement on social media and described it as a deployment of OpenAI’s models into the…

items.title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei calls White House's actions "retaliatory and punitive"
items.standfirst: Hours before Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei's interview, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed the AI company a "supply chain risk to national security," which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic.
items.content: Hours before Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei's interview, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed the AI company a "supply chain risk to national security," which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic.

items.title: Anthropic CEO on "retaliatory and punitive" Pentagon action
items.standfirst: In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive." The Pentagon made the designation, which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic, after the company refused to give the military unfettered access to its AI model.
items.content: In an exclusive interview with CBS News, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said that the Pentagon's decision to designate the AI company a supply chain risk is "retaliatory and punitive." The Pentagon made the designation, which restricts military contractors from doing business with Anthropic, after the company refused to give the military unfettered access to its AI model.

items.title: Anthropic CEO on "red lines" for AI military use: "We wanted to stand up for American values"
items.standfirst: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said in an exclusive interview with CBS News that the AI company sought to draw "red lines" in the government's use of its technology because "we believe that crossing those lines is contrary to American values, and we wanted to stand up for American values." He added: "Disagreeing with the government is the most American thing in the world."
items.content: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei said in an exclusive interview with CBS News that the AI company sought to draw "red lines" in the government's use of its technology because "we believe that crossing those lines is contrary to American values, and we wanted to stand up for American values." He added: "Disagreeing with the government is the most American thing in the world."

items.title: Trump orders US agencies to stop use of Anthropic technology amid dispute over ethics of AI
items.standfirst: Hours after exclusion of Anthropic, OpenAI announces fresh Pentagon deal, but says it will maintain same safety guardrails at the heart of the dispute Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump said Friday he will direct all federal agencies to “IMMEDIATELY CEASE” all use of Anthropic technology in the latest instalment of a very public clash over AI safety.The Department of Defense and Anthropic hit an impasse with neither side backing down as a deadline for an agreement lapsed on Friday afternoon. The Pentagon had demanded the artificial intelligence company loosen ethical guidelines on its AI systems or face severe consequences. Continue reading...
items.content: Hours after exclusion of Anthropic, OpenAI announces fresh Pentagon deal, but says it will maintain same safety guardrails at the heart of the dispute Sign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump said Friday he will direct all federal agencies to “IMMEDIATELY CEASE” all use of Anthropic technology in the latest instalment of a very public clash over AI safety.The Department of Defense and Anthropic hit an impasse with neither side backing down as a deadline for an agreement lapsed on Friday afternoon. The Pentagon had demanded the artificial intelligence company loosen ethical guidelines on its AI systems or face severe consequences. Continue reading...

items.title: OpenAI Gives Pentagon AI Model Access After Anthropic Dustup
items.standfirst: OpenAI has agreed to deploy its own artificial intelligence models within the Defense Department’s classified network after rival Anthropic PBC saw its relationship with the Pentagon implode over surveillance and autonomous weapons concerns.
items.content: OpenAI has agreed to deploy its own artificial intelligence models within the Defense Department’s classified network after rival Anthropic PBC saw its relationship with the Pentagon implode over surveillance and autonomous weapons concerns.

items.title: Trump orders government to stop using Anthropic in battle over AI use

items.content: The move announced on social media comes after a standoff between Anthropic's boss and the Ministry of Defense.

items.title: Hegseth declares Anthropic a "supply chain risk to national security"
items.standfirst: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed artificial intelligence firm Anthropic a supply chain risk on Friday, following days of increasingly heated public conflict with the AI company.
items.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth deemed artificial intelligence firm Anthropic a supply chain risk on Friday, following days of increasingly heated public conflict with the AI company.

items.title: Trump orders federal agencies to stop using Anthropic's AI technology
items.standfirst: President Trump said he will give federal agencies six months to phase out their use of Anthropic's AI products.
items.content: President Trump said he will give federal agencies six months to phase out their use of Anthropic's AI products.

items.content: Anthropic says it would be “legally unsound” for the Pentagon to blacklist its technology after talks over military use of its artificial intelligence models broke down.

items.title: What's at stake in the Pentagon-Anthropic dispute over AI guardrails
items.standfirst: For days, one of America's leading artificial intelligence companies and the Pentagon have been in a standoff over this question: who gets ultimate control over the use of that powerful technology? Jo Ling Kent explains what's at stake.
items.content: For days, one of America's leading artificial intelligence companies and the Pentagon have been in a standoff over this question: who gets ultimate control over the use of that powerful technology? Jo Ling Kent explains what's at stake.

items.title: Trump orders federal agencies to stop using Anthropic as dispute escalates
items.standfirst: There has been a weeks-long feud between Pentagon and Anthropic over concerns about how military could use AI at war.
items.content: There has been a weeks-long feud between Pentagon and Anthropic over concerns about how military could use AI at war.

items.title: Anthropic-Pentagon Hiccup 'Opens Door for OpenAI': Nelson
items.standfirst: Alondra Nelson, Harold F. Linder Professor at the Institute for Advanced Study and a member of the UN advisory body on AI, says she doesn’t believe Anthropic is going anywhere, noting that much can change in the next six months. She speaks with Romaine Bostick and Bailey Lipschultz on “The Close.” (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Alondra Nelson, Harold F. Linder Professor at the Institute for Advanced Study and a member of the UN advisory body on AI, says she doesn’t believe Anthropic is going anywhere, noting that much can change in the next six months. She speaks with Romaine Bostick and Bailey Lipschultz on “The Close.” (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Former Air Force Secretary Frank Kendall calls Trump's order to phase out Anthropic use "outrageous"
items.standfirst: The deadline for artificial intelligence company Anthropic to meet the Pentagon's demands for unrestricted AI access has come and gone without a deal. Frank Kendall, secretary of the Air Force during the Biden administration, joins "The Takeout" with analysis.
items.content: The deadline for artificial intelligence company Anthropic to meet the Pentagon's demands for unrestricted AI access has come and gone without a deal. Frank Kendall, secretary of the Air Force during the Biden administration, joins "The Takeout" with analysis.

items.title: Trump Tells US to Stop Using Anthropic Products
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump directed US government agencies to stop using Anthropic PBC’s products, since the company and Pentagon can't agree on what the AI guardrails should be. Alondra Nelson, a member of the UN advisory board on AI and a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study, discusses this on Bloomberg the Close. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: President Donald Trump directed US government agencies to stop using Anthropic PBC’s products, since the company and Pentagon can't agree on what the AI guardrails should be. Alondra Nelson, a member of the UN advisory board on AI and a professor at the Institute for Advanced Study, discusses this on Bloomberg the Close. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Trump Moves to Ban Anthropic From the US Government
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump’s sudden order comes after the Defense Department pressured Anthropic to drop restrictions on how its AI can be used by the military.
items.content: President Donald Trump’s sudden order comes after the Defense Department pressured Anthropic to drop restrictions on how its AI can be used by the military.

items.title: Why is Anthropic refusing Pentagon demands? #politics
items.standfirst: Company resists military use without safeguards Anthropic, the artificial intelligence firm behind the Claude model, has refused a Pentagon demand to give the Department of Defense unrestricted, unconditional access to its systems. The company’s leadership, including CEO Dario Amodei, argued that…
items.content: Company resists military use without safeguards Anthropic, the artificial intelligence firm behind the Claude model, has refused a Pentagon demand to give the Department of Defense unrestricted, unconditional access to its systems. items.title: OpenAI announces Pentagon deal after Trump bans Anthropic
items.standfirst: Shortly after the president's ban of artificial intelligence company Anthropic, rival OpenAI announced it had done a deal with the Defense Department to provide its technology for classified networks.
items.content: Shortly after the president's ban of artificial intelligence company Anthropic, rival OpenAI announced it had done a deal with the Defense Department to provide its technology for classified networks.(Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

items.title: Anthropic Sees Support From Other Tech Workers in Feud With Pentagon
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC got a vote of support from Silicon Valley workers for its increasingly contentious public-relations battle with the Pentagon over how the military can use artificial intelligence.
items.content: Anthropic PBC got a vote of support from Silicon Valley workers for its increasingly contentious public-relations battle with the Pentagon over how the military can use artificial intelligence.

items.title: Anthropic refuses to bend to Pentagon on AI safeguards
items.standfirst: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.
items.content: A public showdown between the Trump administration and Anthropic is hitting an impasse as military officials demand the artificial intelligence company bend its ethical policies by Friday or risk damaging its business. Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei drew a sharp red line 24 hours before the deadline, declaring his company “cannot in good conscience accede” to the Pentagon’s final demand to allow unrestricted use of its technology.

items.title: DoD officials sent Anthropic final offer for military use of AI, sources say
items.standfirst: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave Anthropic until Friday at 5 p.m. to grant the military unresticted use of its AI technology.
items.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth gave Anthropic until Friday at 5 p.m. to grant the military unresticted use of its AI technology.

items.title: At least 15 killed after military plane carrying banknotes crashes in Bolivia
items.standfirst: Police fire tear gas to disperse crowds allegedly trying to take banknotes from the crash site.
items.content: Police fire tear gas to disperse crowds allegedly trying to take banknotes from the crash site.

items.title: At least 20 killed as cash-laden military cargo plane crashes in Bolivia
items.standfirst: Riot police use teargas to disperse people gathering around wreckage of plane loaded with money from central bankAt least 20 people have died and dozens have been injured after a military cargo plane carrying banknotes crashed while landing near Bolivia’s capital on Friday, damaging about a dozen vehicles on a highway and scattering bills on the ground, an official has said.Footage from local media showed people rushing to collect banknotes while police in riot gear tried to disperse them using teargas. Authorities were later seen setting the money alight in a bonfire at the scene of the crash. Continue reading...
items.content: Riot police use teargas to disperse people gathering around wreckage of plane loaded with money from central bankAt least 20 people have died and dozens have been injured after a military cargo plane carrying banknotes crashed while landing near Bolivia’s capital on Friday, damaging about a dozen vehicles on a highway and scattering bills on the ground, an official has said.Footage from local media showed people rushing to collect banknotes while police in riot gear tried to disperse them using teargas. Authorities were later seen setting the money alight in a bonfire at the scene of the crash. Continue reading...

items.title: Bolivia Plane Carrying Bank Cash Crashes, Killing at Least 10
items.standfirst: A Bolivian military aircraft transporting cash for the central bank crashed near El Alto International Airport in the western part of the country, leaving more than 10 people dead and an unspecified number injured.
items.content: A Bolivian military aircraft transporting cash for the central bank crashed near El Alto International Airport in the western part of the country, leaving more than 10 people dead and an unspecified number injured.

items.title: More than a dozen killed when plane carrying money crashes in Bolivia, official says
items.standfirst: The plane belonging to the Bolivian air force was transporting new banknotes from Bolivia's Central Bank to other cities. A large number of bills were scattered on the ground at the crash site.
items.content: The plane belonging to the Bolivian air force was transporting new banknotes from Bolivia's Central Bank to other cities. A large number of bills were scattered on the ground at the crash site.

items.title: Why was Bill Clinton deposed over Epstein? #politics
items.standfirst: What happened during the deposition Former President Bill Clinton sat for a closed‑door deposition before the House Oversight Committee as part of its probe into Jeffrey Epstein’s network. Lawmakers pressed him about the nature and timing of his relationship with Epstein, the people they…
items.content: What happened during the deposition Former President Bill Clinton sat for a closed‑door deposition before the House Oversight Committee as part of its probe into Jeffrey Epstein’s network. Lawmakers pressed him about the nature and timing of his relationship with Epstein, the people they…

items.title: Bill Clinton says he 'did nothing wrong' with Epstein as he faced grilling over their relationship
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton told members of Congress on Friday that he "did nothing wrong" in his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and saw no signs of Epstein's sexual abuse as he faced hours of grilling from lawmakers over his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton told members of Congress on Friday that he "did nothing wrong" in his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and saw no signs of Epstein's sexual abuse as he faced hours of grilling from lawmakers over his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago.(Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)

items.title: Bill Clinton says in House testimony he had ‘no idea’ about Epstein’s crimes
items.standfirst: ‘I know what I did, and more importantly, what I didn’t do,’ former US president says after six-hour depositionBill Clinton told a congressional committee on Friday he “had no idea of the crimes” Jeffrey Epstein was committing and insisted he “did nothing wrong” in his relationship with the convicted sex trafficker.The former president’s remarks came in his opening statement in a deposition to the House of Representatives’ oversight committee, a day after his wife, Hillary Clinton, appeared before the same body and called the proceedings “partisan political theater” and “an insult to the American people”. Continue reading...
items.content: ‘I know what I did, and more importantly, what I didn’t do,’ former US president says after six-hour depositionBill Clinton told a congressional committee on Friday he “had no idea of the crimes” Jeffrey Epstein was committing and insisted he “did nothing wrong” in his relationship with the convicted sex trafficker.The former president’s remarks came in his opening statement in a deposition to the House of Representatives’ oversight committee, a day after his wife, Hillary Clinton, appeared before the same body and called the proceedings “partisan political theater” and “an insult to the American people”. Continue reading...

items.title: Bill Clinton asked about hot tub photo and testifies he knew 'nothing' of Epstein crimes
items.standfirst: The former president told the committee that he would never have flown on Epstein's plane if he "had any inkling of what he was doing".
items.content: The former president told the committee that he would never have flown on Epstein's plane if he "had any inkling of what he was doing".

items.title: Bill Clinton at Epstein deposition: "I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong"
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton denied any knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein's crimes in an opening statement before the House Oversight Committee in New York.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton denied any knowledge of Jeffrey Epstein's crimes in an opening statement before the House Oversight Committee in New York.

items.content: The former US president, who is featured in photographs within the Epstein files, denies having any knowledge of the convicted sex offender's crimes.

During his appearance he denied any knowledge of Epstein’s criminal…

items.title: Bill Clinton faces grilling from lawmakers over his connections to Jeffrey Epstein
items.standfirst: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.
items.content: Former President Bill Clinton is testifying Friday before members of Congress investigating convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, answering for his connections to the disgraced financier from more than two decades ago. The closed-door deposition in Chappaqua, comes a day after Clinton's wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, sat with lawmakers for her own deposition. France 24's Jessica Le Masurier has the latest from Chappaqua.

items.title: Takeaways from Hillary Clinton's deposition. And, Paramount outbids for Warner Bros.
items.standfirst: Hillary Clinton says the questioning in a closed-door deposition with the House Oversight Committee's Epstein investigation was repetitive. And, Paramount has outbid Netflix for Warner Bros.
items.content: Hillary Clinton says the questioning in a closed-door deposition with the House Oversight Committee's Epstein investigation was repetitive. And, Paramount has outbid Netflix for Warner Bros.(Image credit: Charly Triballeau)

clusters.title: US backs Pakistan’s ‘right to defend itself’ against Taliban after strikes on Afghanistan
clusters.neutral_headline: Afghanistan’s Taliban says open to talks after Pakistan bombs major cities
bullet_summary: Pakistan's defence minister has said the ​country ‌is in an "open ​war" with neighbouring Afghanistan, after both nations launched strikes overnight
Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly airstrikes

items.title: US backs Pakistan’s ‘right to defend itself’ against Taliban after strikes on Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Taliban offer to resolve dispute via dialogue after Pakistan bombed cities in Afghanistan in latest escalation with its neighbourWashington endorsed Pakistan’s “right to defend itself” after it bombed major cities across Afghanistan amid heightened tensions between the two hostile neighbours.The Taliban government in Kabul stressed it was ready to negotiate on Friday as violence intensified between the two countries. Continue reading...
items.content: Taliban offer to resolve dispute via dialogue after Pakistan bombed cities in Afghanistan in latest escalation with its neighbourWashington endorsed Pakistan’s “right to defend itself” after it bombed major cities across Afghanistan amid heightened tensions between the two hostile neighbours.The Taliban government in Kabul stressed it was ready to negotiate on Friday as violence intensified between the two countries. Continue reading...

items.title: Afghanistan’s Taliban says open to talks after Pakistan bombs major cities
items.standfirst: The Taliban says its leaders willing to negotiate with Pakistan as both sides claim to inflict heavy losses in fighting.
items.content: The Taliban says its leaders willing to negotiate with Pakistan as both sides claim to inflict heavy losses in fighting.

items.title: Pakistan and Afghanistan trade deadly strikes
items.standfirst: Pakistan declared “open war” on Afghanistan after the two countries traded attacks in a sharp escalation following months of tensions. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on what led to fighting between the neighboring nations.
items.content: Pakistan declared “open war” on Afghanistan after the two countries traded attacks in a sharp escalation following months of tensions. NBC News' Raf Sanchez reports on what led to fighting between the neighboring nations.

items.title: Pakistan declares 'open war' against Afghanistan
items.standfirst: #Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Kabul and three other Afghan provinces overnight between Thursday and Friday, authorities in #Afghanistan said, as the former's defence minister said that the countries were now in "open war".
items.content: #Pakistan conducted airstrikes in Kabul and three other Afghan provinces overnight between Thursday and Friday, authorities in #Afghanistan said, as the former's defence minister said that the countries were now in "open war".

items.title: Civilians flee fighting after Pakistan bombs Afghan cities
items.standfirst: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.
items.content: After an Afghan cross-border attack on Thursday night, Pakistan carried out overnight strikes on Kabul and declared what it called an “open war” with Afghanistan, sending civilians in border areas fleeing to safety.

items.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan conflict: 'Localised clashes still going on'
items.standfirst: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.
items.content: Localised clashes are still continuing along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border while Taliban officials say Pakistani aircraft continue to fly over Afghanistan's territory, reports France 24's correspondent Shahzaib Wahlah, following Pkaistan's bombing of major cities in Afghanistan including the capital Kabul on Friday.

items.title: Pakistan declares state of ‘open war’ after bombing major Afghan cities
items.standfirst: Wave of strikes comes after Taliban forces attack Pakistani border troops following earlier action from IslamabadPakistan has bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital, Kabul, with Islamabad’s defence minister declaring that the hostile neighbours were in a state of “open war” as a cycle of retaliatory attacks escalated further.Witnesses in Kabul and Kandahar, the southern Afghan city, reported explosions and jets overhead until dawn, while the Taliban government said later that Pakistani surveillance aircraft were still flying over Afghanistan. Continue reading...
items.content: Wave of strikes comes after Taliban forces attack Pakistani border troops following earlier action from IslamabadPakistan has bombed major cities in Afghanistan including the capital, Kabul, with Islamabad’s defence minister declaring that the hostile neighbours were in a state of “open war” as a cycle of retaliatory attacks escalated further.Witnesses in Kabul and Kandahar, the southern Afghan city, reported explosions and jets overhead until dawn, while the Taliban government said later that Pakistani surveillance aircraft were still flying over Afghanistan. Continue reading...

items.title: Pakistan’s ‘open war’ on Afghanistan follows years of tensions
items.standfirst: The Pakistani government declared “open war” on the Taliban authorities on Friday after an Afghan offensive launched on Thursday on its border led Islamabad to bomb Kabul in retaliation. But these tensions between the two neighboring countries are not new; they have been going on for years and have been exacerbated since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.

items.title: Trump advisers scramble to justify possible US military intervention in Iran
items.standfirst: Tehran’s ICBMs cannot currently reach the US, experts say, and White House has claimed its nuclear programme has been destroyedSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump’s likely casus belli for an attack on Iran – which would be the largest US intervention since the Iraq war – is fraught with contradictions, and his top advisers have been left to cover for him as the White House makes the case for intervention.In his State of the Union address this week, Trump alleged that Iran posed a direct threat to the US and that the country was “working to build missiles that will soon reach the United States of America”. But that claim has not been backed up with evidence by the White House or the Pentagon, and US intelligence reports from just last year say that it would take Iran 10 years to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach the US. Continue reading...
items.content: Tehran’s ICBMs cannot currently reach the US, experts say, and White House has claimed its nuclear programme has been destroyedSign up for the Breaking News US email to get newsletter alerts in your inboxDonald Trump’s likely casus belli for an attack on Iran – which would be the largest US intervention since the Iraq war – is fraught with contradictions, and his top advisers have been left to cover for him as the White House makes the case for intervention.In his State of the Union address this week, Trump alleged that Iran posed a direct threat to the US and that the country was “working to build missiles that will soon reach the United States of America”. But that claim has not been backed up with evidence by the White House or the Pentagon, and US intelligence reports from just last year say that it would take Iran 10 years to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile that could reach the US. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says 'not happy' with Iran talks, but undecided on possible military action
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".
items.content: US President Donald Trump said on Friday he was "not happy" with the way Iran was negotiating in talks with the US, but had not yet made a "final decision" on whether the US would launch military action against Tehran. His comments came as the US advised its non-emergency embassy staff to leave Israel "due to safety risks".

items.title: Russia may interfere in Danish election, exploiting chaos sewn by US, spies warn
items.standfirst: US threats to seize Greenland have created ‘new international fault lines’ that can be used to spread disinformation, Danish intelligence agencies sayDenmark’s intelligence services have warned that a foreign power may try to sway the general election on 24 March, saying the main threat was from Russia over support for Ukraine but also citing the chaos caused by US efforts to seize Greenland.The PET police intelligence service and FE military intelligence said in a joint statement the election campaign could be marked by disinformation and cyberattacks “to sow division, influence the public debate or to target candidates, parties or specific political programmes”. Continue reading...
items.content: US threats to seize Greenland have created ‘new international fault lines’ that can be used to spread disinformation, Danish intelligence agencies sayDenmark’s intelligence services have warned that a foreign power may try to sway the general election on 24 March, saying the main threat was from Russia over support for Ukraine but also citing the chaos caused by US efforts to seize Greenland.The PET police intelligence service and FE military intelligence said in a joint statement the election campaign could be marked by disinformation and cyberattacks “to sow division, influence the public debate or to target candidates, parties or specific political programmes”. Continue reading...
